title: 105_s428
content: The "Child Safety Lock Act of 1997" may also be referred to as the Handgun Safety Act. The term 'locking device' is defined as a mechanism on a firearm that prevents discharge without deactivating it with a key or combination lock. The Child Safety Lock Act of 1997 prohibits licensed manufacturers, importers, or dealers from selling handguns without providing a locking device to the buyer. The Child Safety Lock Act of 1997 requires handguns to be sold with a warning about responsible firearm storage, emphasizing the need to store firearms unloaded, locked, and separate from ammunition to prevent access by children. Failure to do so may result in legal consequences. The Child Safety Lock Act of 1997 mandates responsible firearm storage for handguns, with exceptions for law enforcement and rail police officers. The Child Safety Lock Act of 1997 requires responsible handgun storage, with exemptions for law enforcement officers certified by a state and employed by a rail carrier for law enforcement purposes. Amendments to Section 924 of title 18, United States Code, include penalties for violations related to locking devices and warnings. The Child Safety Lock Act of 1997 mandates responsible handgun storage, with penalties including license suspension, revocation, or civil penalties up to $10,000. Actions by the Secretary can be reviewed under section 923(f), and administrative remedies are still available despite these penalties.
